Ed Wynn was classic as Uncle Albert by the way, but it seemed out of character for Mary to be so down on the 'laugh out loud' aspect of Albert's character. Here she was trying to convey a sense of wonder and happiness to her two young wards, and frowning upon those ridiculous jokes seemed out of place. But that aside, I had a pretty good time with the picture, and if I had to pick a favorite scene, I thought the penguin sequence with Bert (Van Dyke) was very cleverly done.

reviews.review_title: Classic musical comedy with joyous dance set pieces and a plethora of hit songs
reviews.content: Julie Andrews plays a nany who believes that ¨a spoonful of sugar makes the medicine go down¨. She is a magical nanny arriving one day on the East Wind and takes over a household of a very proper London banker . As the beloved and nearly perfect nanny, Mary Poppins, descends from the sky to lend a hand . As the good family is visited by the enigmatic Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews) following other maids . Through her unique magical skills, and with the aid of her friend Bert , a pavement artist , she helps the family rediscover the joy and wonder missing in their lives. She introduces her two charges (Matthew Garber, Karen Dotrice) to her friends , the chimney sweep (Dick Van Dyke with a pawky cockney accent) and eccentric uncle Albert (Ed Wynn) . All of them embark on a magical adventure, and what is more exciting, they will even get to find happiness again. Is there anything that a dash of optimism can't cure? See It Again and Again with that Supercalifragilistic Music! . In a place we hold dear, where wonder once lived... but soon from above, a fantastic story begins. This Christmas, when you lose your way, just remember the magic always returns. It's supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!Based on the books by P. L. Travers taking the magic , adventure , happiness , optimism and good feeling from the fantastic novels . Julie Andrews in her film debut as the maid who changes the lives of everyone in the family , from her they learn that life can always be happy and joyous if you take the proper perspective . Andrews was unjustly ignored for the movie version of ¨My Fair Lady¨ by George Cukor , in spite of Julie played on stage , being replaced by Audrey Hepburn , but Julie bounced back to win an Academy Award as the magical mystery nanny who changes the lives of of the Banks family for the better . Andrews is great in the title role and sings ever so sweetly , including charming songs being well composed by musician Irwin Kostal . The songs and dance numbers are attractively laid on , with Dick Van Dyke as Mary's Cockney beau , giving a fun acting and dancing splendidly , as well . Dick Van Dyke is awesome and dancing his way to movie stardom . Look for the marvellous sequence where Van Dyke as cheerfully resourceful sweep, and one-man band dances with animated penguins , along with the chimney sweeps on the rooftops . Support cast are frankly fabulous , such as Edd Wynn as uncle who floats when he laughs , and the likable parents : David Tomlinson and Glynis Johns are delightful. Don't forget to stay tuned for the last line of the credits . A Disney classic that hasn't lost any lost any of its magic . It displays a colorful and brilliant cinematography by cameraman Edward Colman , Walt Disney's regular. The motion picture was stunningly directed by Robert Stevenson. He was a a prestigious director and writer, who used to work for Walt Disney factory , and known for Mary Poppins (1964), Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971) and Tudor Rose (1936). He is the only director to be nominated for the Best Director Academy Award for directing a Disney movie. He has directed two films that have been selected for the National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically or aesthetically" significant : Old Yeller (1957) and Mary Poppins (1964).Followed many years later by ¨Mary Poppins Returns¨ (2018) by Rob Marshall with Emily Blunt , Ben Whishaw , Julie Walters , Colin Firth , Meryl Streep, Lin-Manuel Miranda , Emily Mortimer , Pixie Davies. This sequel to the 1964 Disney film 'Mary Poppins' opens in London, England during a time that is being called a Great Slump , the Great Depression of the 1930s.

reviews.review_title: Why can't all nannies be like Mary Poppins?
reviews.content: Dame Julie Andrews won an Academy Award for her performance in this film as Mary Poppins, the nanny ever child and adults loves. In this film, the supporting cast includes the wonderfully talented and big television star, Dick Van Dyke (he deserves to get America's honors such as the Kennedy Center Honors for example), as her friend with a 100 jobs, Bert which includes chimney sweeper and sidewalk artist. The wonderful Glynis Johns (who should also be honored with Damehood like Julie) is fantastic as Mrs. Banks. The children, Michael and Jane, are also great performers. I can't forget Elsa Lancaster as the last nanny before Mary Poppins. The film is a timeless classic for children and adults. I remember as a child watching it on television before the popularity of DVDs and VHS cassettes. This was a time when we used our memories to remember the brilliant animation, costumes, art direction, and cinematography of the movies as well as the acting and writing and in this movie as well as the singing.

Genre: Family film with real people, Julie Andrews, musical, positive feeling.Main characters: Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews), Bert (Dick van Dyke), Jane and Michael.What happens: Jane and Michael need a nanny, after their last one went off in huff. What Mr. Banks doesn't expect is a nanny arriving responding to an advert he tore up and threw in the fireplace..!My thoughts: This is a very lovely film, charming for both children and adults. You are likely to enjoy the songs, the actors or/and the story. Those who have read the book/s may think of this as a little bit of a mess of P.L Travers's work, but of course if you haven't read them then you will definitely think otherwise. This film also has a good amount of humour, performed mainly by Julie Andrews and Glynnis John ( :-) ). Whatever you have read the book or not, you will love this film in at least one little way or another. If you do not, then I am sorry that I have failed you and maybe you like horror films or something like that. If I have not, then I am glad you enjoyed this and maybe then you will be interested in reading the book. Recommended to: Families and people who like musicals. Enjoy! :-)

reviews.review_title: Has a whole lot going for it, but...
reviews.content: Here's a movie that you would think would never go wrong, but director Stevenson evidently disagreed. Instead of a cinema feature aimed for a long release at the best cinemas in the country, Stevenson obviously thought Disney's best bet was a quick salvage sale to TV. Nevertheless, despite Stevenson's lack of cinema craftsmanship and some obvious deficiencies in Dick Van Dyke's performance, this film is still a delight. It's packed out with catchy songs, eye-catching sets and superb, absolutely faultless special effects. The story provides a wonderfully magical combination of whimsy, fancy and fantasy - all of it superbly realized. Perhaps some of the cartoon creatures are a bit too cute, but the magnificent sets and rollicking choreography allied with the never-ending magic carpet of surprises and effects, plus such excellent performances and delightful singing...

A big part of me would like to describe this movie with the word "supercalifragilisticexpialidocious." Unfortunately, if I'm being honest, it doesn't warrant that kind of superlative. It's an entertaining movie, great for kids if a little bit long for their attention span, with a number of noticeable weaknesses carried along for the ride and featuring a cast who were all good, but who could all do better, as they would subsequently prove. The first thing that interested me was that although Julie Andrews was playing the title character as the mysteriously magical nanny who turns a prim and proper British household upside down, she wasn't really the movie's star. To me, that was clearly Dick Van Dyke as Bert, who injected most of the fun into the movie, albeit doing it with a pathetically phoney Cockney (?) accent. David Tomlinson was along for the ride as Mr. Banks, the head of the household into which Mary Poppins literally falls.Of the three leads, Andrews' talent was underused - as would become clear after "The Sound of Music" the following year, Van Dyke - while he injected fun into the movie - seemed to lack the energy that he displayed a few years later in the somewhat similar "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang" (which I thought was marginally better than this) and Tomlinson put on a better performance a few years after that in "Bedknobs and Broomsticks" (which I didn't think was as good as this.) As for the movie itself, there was some successful mixing of live action/animation (although that bit went on too long) and some decent enough special effects for 1964, although the sets weren't especially realistic. Overall, it's a good movie; one that I would describe as solid but not spectacular. 7/10

I am constantly musing on why musicals generally cannot instigate my appetite, my favorite ones include MOULIN ROUGE! 2001 and CHICAGO 2002, while the missing link is the more vintage ones, so yesterday I conquered another musical classics MARY POPPINS (1964), and the afterthought comes with an equivocal feeling, I think one major drawback fends me off against musicals is that I am so accustomed to the narrative intensity of films notwithstanding that we are aware they are all fictional, thus when episodic singing and dancing interrupts, I cannot help but enjoy it like watching a show or MTV, which could be palatable for one time maybe, but an entire feature-length musical is not something I intend to assimilate. MARY POPPINS is hardly an exception but at the same time it is too cute and bewitchingly edifying to dislike, it had also been a sensational triumph hark back to its time, what admiring is also the avant-garde technology in the film industry per se, the mash-up of real people and the animation, is my favorite and the dancing sequences of the chimney workers is such a scene without tainting its fame after more than half a century. After all it's a family film which I may have watched it belatedly and the cartoonish characterizations are outmoded, still its overwhelming victory in the Oscars (5 wins including a BEST ACTRESS win for the novice Julie Andrews) is too merciful for the film, for nowadays it is quite impossible to imagine a family-film could sweep like that, actually I think Dick Van Dyke's strenuous effort merits more applause indeed!

reviews.review_title: I enjoyed this more when I was six
reviews.content: Watching Mary Poppins for the first time since I was a child, I began musing on the difference between watching this movie as an adult as opposed to the Wizard of Oz. Oz is, like most child-friendly movies of the 30s and 40s, a piece of entertainment focused on children but aimed at everyone. This is why it holds up so beautifully.Poppins, on the other hand, is focused not on children as subject (the children are simply participants in the lives of unusual adults) but on a child's eye view of the world. This works great if you're a kid, but as an adult, the movie's episodic structure, superficial characterizations and lack of real drama (Oz was a far more intense emotional experience) feels a little dull and definitely childish.Mary Poppins has some very good elements. Julie Andrews is excellent as the magical, no-nonsense nanny. Dick Van Dyke, in spite of the awful accent, uses his distinctive physicality well, especially in the marvelous chimney sweep number Step in Time (which I probably didn't care for as a child; I wasn't much into long musical extravaganzas). Performances are quite good, and there are amusing moments throughout.Mary Poppins is typical of the very kid-focused approach of their 1960s movies, which I loved growing up but which don't hold up to adult viewings the way movies like Miracle on 34th Street or Toy Story do. If I had a kid, I would certainly want them to see this one, but as an adult, I wouldn't care to watch it again.

reviews.review_title: It's practically perfect in every way.
reviews.content: Mary Poppins is a classic. The story is unique, the characters are memorable and the music is magical. Granted, the first half of the movie is much more engaging for children than the last half, but this is still one of the great ones. It's no wonder that this film has stood the test of time -- it's practically perfect in every way.

Mary Poppins is one of the few excellent movies you can watch with the whole family, even with the little ones - the world needs more movies like Mary Poppins. Julie Andrews gives an excellent performance, the cast rock solid, the production fantastic. Mary Poppins will entertain and excite generations still to come. Classic.

I may be in the minority here, but after having tried to endure the full 2 hours and 20 minutes of this as an adult, I fully understood why I never liked it much as a child. It is not focused on children but mostly on the grown-ups around them. Mary Poppins appears out of nowhere and leaves just as fast, dumping the children who got attached to her. Some of the songs seem completely unrelated to the story (the woman feeding the birds, etc) and are quite sad, Mrs. Banks has almost no part of the story, Mr. Banks has way too much, but he seems a deranged character. There are too many song and dance numbers, some very loud, most overlong. Some scenes are irrelevant to the plot development (if there is any) and there is a lot of banking and old men, none in the least entertaining.The only part I liked was the one with the animation, which I just discovered, was the one the author (PL Travers) hated most. Actually, she hated the whole movie, but for reasons different from mine. Some may object that this movie got Oscars, to which I can just add that Oscars - now and in the past - do seem to be distributed randomly, or for politically correct reasons.

Mary Poppins is regarded as a Disney classic but is also an overlong film that is not as amusing as it think it is but it does have catchy songs.Jane and Michael Banks are two kids in a middle class London suburb in the Edwardian era. The parents are distant from them and they cause chaos to each of their nannies employed to look after them.Their father, a banker is cold and uninvolved. Their mother spends more time as a suffragette.The parents are looking for the perfect nanny and in a gust of wind Mary Poppins drops by with her umbrella. Possessing magical powers such as a bottomless handbag, Mary Poppins changes the life of the children and re-acquaints with her friend Bert, the one man band.The film combines live action with Disney animation as well as some memorable songs and in Dick Van Dyke an even more memorable cockney accent.There is a stage element to this adaptation of a book but it is not all that it is cracked up to be. The parents elicit little sympathy, Mary and Bert along with the kids drive the film along and the animation is rather flat I felt.I can kind of understand why the author PL Travers was underwhelmed by the film's adaptation.

reviews.review_title: A SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS Fantasy film that everyone wish to come true..
reviews.content:
A SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS Fantasy film that everyone wish to come true. I am no child now but i wish i was to enjoy the fantasy film keeping all the review stuff aside for a while. It doesn't really matter because i am 28 and i still loved watching Mary Poppins. I just wish i had seen it in childhood and it would have became one of those nostalgic memento of my life. Although Mary Poppins is a fairy tale, many people believed the main message came out of it. Life is a busy horse and one must learn to rein it on right time. Walt Disney's fantasy world seems quite enjoyable with delightful music and meaningful lyrics. The art direction and editing at some places is treat to watch. That one entire scene of Painting World is absolutely marvellous. Julia Andrews get an unforgettable feature film debut as she looks elegant as Mary Poppins just as they required Rosy cheeks, blue eyes and Kind. Divk Van Dyke does some terrific dancing moves and thoss childrens Karen Dotrice & Matthew Garber brings the naturalism into thier cute characters. David Tomlinson as strict and driven father looks convincing while Glynis Johns as his wife is Decent. Director Robert Stevenson made a few changes in the script from the original book but got all of them right, also he presented a live action animated film so accurately for that era. The film won 5 Oscars competiting another Musical Classic 'My Fair Lady' and that says so much about it being awesome. Overall, Mary Poppins is a pleasant musical fantasy that can be enjoyed by all ages and I wouldn't mind if it comes true in my life.
Rating- 7/10*

I'd like to think that I've seen a lot of movies, of varying quality and genre; enough to believe I have at least a basic grasp of cinema as a whole. But during all the classics and tripe I've endured over the years, Mary Poppins has somehow managed to evade me. I was too busy watching rabbits getting torn to pieces in Watership Down (1978) and clapping giddily at Rocky Balboa's training montage in Rocky (1976) as a child to be distracted by something quite as colourful as this. So, it's at the ripe old age of 28 that I came round to sitting through Mary Poppins, to struggle through its squeaky-clean visage and many, many songs that I somehow knew all the words to before seeing the film. Well, I was wrong to be so cynical, as although the film is hardly what I would call a classic, it's really rather good.London, 1910. Merry jack-of-all-trades Bert (Dick Van Dyke) is playing a one-man-band to an enthusiastic street audience when he senses something magical in the air, signalling the return of his good friend Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews). He takes us into the stable yet unhappy Banks' family home, where the household is ran by lord-of-his-castle Mr. Banks (David Tomlinson), and his suffragette wife Mrs. Banks (Glynis Johns). Busy attending to work and other matters, the Banks' have started to neglect their children, Jane (Karen Dotrice) and Michael (Matthew Garber). After their umpteenth nanny walks out on them, Mr. Banks makes a desperate newspaper plea for a nanny who will lay down the law, and teach the children respect and the harshness of life. So enters Mary Poppins, 'perfect in every way', a nanny who is as strict as she needs to be but one capable of also showing the children the joys of life.Mary Poppins suffers mainly from the same thing that I feel plagues most musicals - it's too long. Seemingly every musical feels the need to round-up every change of emotion and sub-plot with a grand song-and- dance number that gets old quickly. The first half of the film is pure family entertainment, with memorable songs and some stunning special effects (for its day) making the film zip by happily. Then the songs get more clunky and forgettable, and we are exposed to much more of Dick Van Dyke's terrible accent and his grating, over-enthusiastic Bert than we need (although I'm sure he has his many fans). Yet after the somewhat exhausting 139 minutes is over, Poppins still leaves you with that cuddly feeling inside, something I thought had died inside me when I sprouted my first pube.Most of the success of Poppins comes from the performance of Julie Andrews. All sweet and idyllic, she could have come across as a stuck-up Miss Perfect, but Andrews' effortless likability and stage experience makes her more of a supernatural missionary, sent to make a stand against Mr. Banks' stern and rigid outlook on life. Disney were really coming out of their Golden Era at the time of this being released, but it's still one of their most fondly remembered, and certainly their most critically successful live-action efforts. It's more than likely that children will turn away from it, due to the mega-bucks spewed into children's films these days, but it will continue to enchant adults, especially those that grew up with it, and even those new to it, like me. Chim-chimernee, chim-ernee, chim chim, cheroo! Damn it, it's in my head again!

Warning do not read unless seen movie.One of the things I love about the fantasy genre is how in some of the positive stories it really can give you a good feeling even in times when you down, by showing you there really is a bigger world out there beyond your own sight or your own current existence. This is another one of my favorite fantasy films of all time, I've seen this when I was about 7 years old I loved it them and even as an adult I love it now. As a kid as I said I was really into the fantasy genre, seeing a lady flying with an umbrella, being this fantastic being, and taking kids on an extraordinary fantasy adventure it really blew me away.The setting is unique as it takes place in London in the 1900 which is a perfect setting as it's was the turn of the century, a time of great change when new ideas and ideals were on the rise and certain old customs and thinking was starting to go out of fashion. Really like the story which is sort of the guardian angel motif but here it's done in a sort of quirky fairy tale like fashion. I really love the concept of the hidden fantasy world in the contemporary existence which was unique at the time, though now common place in the genre with shows like "The Adventures of Pete and Pete", "Sailor Moon", etc.Julie Andrews is just perfect as Mary Poppins, this is my favorite role from her as she truly is this character much as Christopher Reeve is "Superman" or Gene Wilder is "Willy Wonka". Anyway, she is just perfect (the measurement tape she carries of course justifies it.), she's a person that is really stern and serious but she's not oh so serious, deep down she's really a quirky strange warm hearted individual but she doesn't let it show, she keeps it hidden with that mask of sternness, but she does take that mask off little by little as she grows close to the kids and some of her time with her friend Bert. I just love how she just has this dry sense of humor and wit about her, she's got a lot of memorable lines and charisma and as usual she has that lovely singing voice. She was the kind of person I really wish I had as a babysitter as she not just helps show the kids a good time and fantasy world but just bonds with them beautifully and is understanding of whatever trouble them.Dick Van Dyke is just great as Bert this is my favorite role from him, as he just like Mary he's just as strange and has magic powers like her. Though he's a bit the opposite as he's a person that isn't so prim and proper, he puts out what he thinks and feels he doesn't feel the need to keep it all in. One thing I really like about him is that he's not a person concerned about looks, despite how dirty he may look or how he dresses, he's a person that simply likes to do things that make him feel good.It's great when we see both Mary and Bert together, they both have just great back and forth together and in a way really are good for each other as Bert really brings a sense of fun and humor to Mary's seriousness and even though Mary doesn't want to show it she really does have a good time with him, I get the feeling he's probably the only guy that really makes her smile and possibly laugh. You also get the feeling that both could be more than just friends, your never quite sure but there are little suttle hints throughout the film. And of course, both bond with the kids well, in a way their both the aunt and uncle they never had.I really love that both are people that are down to Earth like anyone else and yet there not. In a way are sort of like the Time Lords in "Doctor Who", like with The Doctor they take the kids whom you can say are the Earthbound companions temporarily to where ever. And like the Doctor there is this great enigmatic quality as we never really know who they really are and where they come from, both could be aliens for all I know, Mary did come from the sky after all hmmm. Their both always full of surprises as we discover little bits of depth and constantly develop which to me keeps these characters interesting and likeable, as opposed to characters in some TV shows have that fundamental problem of become overdeveloped or overexposed to the point of being less interesting.The effects are good, I wouldn't say anything mind-blowingly extraordinary but are effective all the same at giving the illusion that both Bert and Mary Poppins have some magical abilities but also the hidden fantasy world that exists around them. Really like the snapping effect which is of course the simple reverse photography method, I though it was really could that you can get things done by simply snapping your fingers much like the clap on lights. Though my favorite effect believe it or not is seeing Bert, Mary and the kids jump into Bert's check drawings and we see they all are in a world of animation which I though was cool I which I could do that with the comic books and manga I read.The songs are all memorable, their the kind I could listen too on my iPod sometimes. The sequences are all well done and choregraphed. I'll just say three of the songs and sequences which are my favorites. First one is "I Love to Laugh" that scene is just one you can't help but laugh toward, it reminds me of those laugh gas scenes you would see in movies or sitcoms it's just so infectious as it is ridiculous. Just seeing Mary's Uncle Albert whom is of course played by comedian Ed Wynn, he was just funny as he just floating around because he laughs a lot, and of course we see other character join in. Though it's even funnier as we see how they get down which shows how tragedy and comedy can really go together.Second is "Chim chimney /Stepping time" alright I know it's a bit of a cheat but both the song and the dance number sort of go together. The song is such a calm nice yet fun and catchy song, it's fun when we see Bert along with Mary Poppins and the kids go up on the roof tops with him and their riding a smoke cloud and then hearing Mary sing the song making it even better. The Stepping Time dance number was just a lot of fun and a little exhausting to watch at the same time as it is just constant activity, I really love how well choregraphed it is as we see the Chimney Sweepers and even Bert and Mary do all different kinds of dance formations like popping in and out of chimneys, going into what looks like a bit of a ho down, the list goes on. It's gets even more fun, wild and funny as the sea captain character whom makes his roof into a ship and even runs it like one (I'm not kidding) mistakes them for Pirates and shoots fireworks at them, even see Bert hit one like a golf ball (also not kidding) and they all retreat and continue the dance elsewhere. Though all admit this whole sequence as fun as it is, it also kind of made me want to take a shower from the amount of black smoke and seeing how dirty everyone is, though I'll admit Mary still looked good despite how dirty she looked.Though of course my favorite song is "Supercalifragislistic expalidoshious" this one is just so much fun and full of energy and catchy, let along the longest nonexistent phrase ever. Just everything about this scene is perfect as it's not just song and dance chirography that is spot on, both Julie and Dick look like their having fun, but just the use of both live action and animation together.Despite all the fantasy this film really does have a heart as we see Mary Poppins and Bert we're just there to help the Children but were also there to help the father George Banks played well by David Tomlinson whom is a person on the overly strict side of things, he's not a bad father at all just on the wrong track. We see throughout things George begins to realize despite his pursuit of success he's missing time with his family but also missing out on life. The film does have a good message on realizing what's more important in life but also to experience the joys life has to offer no matter what age you are.Mary Poppins flies high in the sky and into our hearts.Rating: 4 stars

I see the film with the memories of child who I was. Same fascination. Same magic. The songs and the penguins and the woman with pigeons on Saint Paul staires. And each try to critic it becomes biyarre. It is "Mary Poppins". That "Mary Poppins", which has all the tools for be defined as fascinating by entire family.Because, decade by decade, it becomes a film about yourself. For kite and spoonful of sugar and for the unique Julie Andrews ( and too charming Dyck van Dycke )

reviews.review_title: Well... no. There is no magic but special effects.
reviews.content: Mary Poppins, hop in for a mediocre experience! Well, there are those movies, that just don't stand the test time, or other stated, age as well as Mickey Rourke. This is one of them. At the time of its release, it was a masterpiece of special effects, combining animated with live action cinematography. Also, the music of the Sherman Brothers was outstanding and the latter one remains an untouchable holy grail of songwriting today. But for the rest of the movie? Sigh.What you are about to witness is nothing, but an incoherent mess. One scene bunched after the other, just for the purpose of getting from one song to the next. Nothing makes any sense at all - besides from a loose conceptual framework of two kids being neglected by their parents - the whole movie consists of only singular events, everyone of them seemingly going on forever, without any connection, a greater story, character development, nothing has anything to do with anything.The successor, Disney Bednobs and Broomsticks, again with music by the Sherman Brothers and following the same concept of mixing animated with live cinematography, is another matter altogether and showcases, how to do it right. A beautiful story, brilliant songs, weaved careful together while the movie progresses, characters connect with each other and the audience and the music itself is not decoration, but integrated core of the plot.If you leave nostalgia behind, this movie really fails in every aspect of simple movie-making ABC and the author of Mary Poppins, Pamela Travers, rejected this movie in total for good reasons. Today we can understand that she had every right to criticize it. It simply does not justify the original book. Worse, it barely has anything to do with the stories from the book. And even worse, it does not even hold up as a good movie by itself.Don't bother watching, get Bedknobs and Broomsticks instead.

reviews.review_title: One of the best musicals ever made
reviews.content: Surely one of the best musicals ever made, and a great movie, full stop. Great feel-good movie, filled with innocence and emotion, whimsy and fantasy. I am generally not into musicals, but the songs make this movie. The music moves the movie along, and provides the moments of fantasy and whimsy.Julie Andrews deserves all the kudos she has received for this movie, and her Best Leading Actress Oscar. Solid supporting cast, especially Dick van Dyke and the two kids, Karen Dotrice and Matthew Garber.An absolute must-see.

reviews.review_title: What A Difference A Song Makes
reviews.content: If you're looking for a film with high technical quality across all cinematic crafts and trades ... this is it. The screen story, set in 1910, about a magical nanny who comes down from the clouds, literally, to care for, and be the nursemaid of, two English children, is original and engaging. Humor and low-intensity conflict propel the plot to a finale that is appropriate, given Walt Disney's objective of entertaining the audience. Characters are sympathetic and likable. Taken as a whole, the story clearly foreshadows the woman's liberation movement of the 60s and 70s. And the plot contains occasional tributes to vaudeville.Long before CGI and even this film, Disney's innovations in animation and special effects enhanced the movie-going experience. In "Mary Poppins" those innovations reach a zenith, not only because the technical complexity is so adroitly concealed, but also because the animation and special effects contribute to the story, instead of being the story. Mary Poppins, the lady, is a magic nanny, but "Mary Poppins", the film, is also nanny magic.Aside from the screen story, other traditional movie crafts also excel in this film. Stevenson's direction is fine, given Disney's objective. The plot zooms along at a nice clip. Production design is lush; costumes are intricate; and the acting is wonderful. All the songs are marvelous, and several of them have retained their popularity to this day.My only disappointment relates to the film's somewhat shallow theme. If Disney had been so inclined, and clearly he was not, he could have made a few changes that would have rendered a film with deeper, more metaphysical, import. A good analogy here would be "The Wizard Of Oz", a children's film wherein the symbolism and metaphysics could fill a bottomless pit. As is, the theme of "Mary Poppins" goes no deeper than the optimistic notion that a little bit of effort can fix a serious problem. That theme expresses itself via "A Spoonful Of Sugar" and "Let's Go Fly A Kite". I would have preferred a cryptic theme, via the more mystical "Chim-Chim-Cheree".Be that as it may, "Mary Poppins" is still a great film for kids, and can be enjoyed by adults, too. It's a quality act, all the way. It's a film whose music is so original and melodic that it's hard to get some of those catchy tunes out of one's head, especially, for me ... "Chim-Chim-Cheree".

Before anyhiing else, I would like to say a few things:1. The acting and singing in "Mary Poppins" is SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS2. I really really loved the live-action/animation parts. If that was the entire movie, I'd give this film 10/10 stars3. I understand why this movie is beloved by many. This movie was fun. I did not love nor hated it. It's just fun. "Mary Poppins" is the kind of movie that did not work 100% for me but is beloved by millions and being beloved by millions is a SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS achievement. Despite the fact that I did not enjoy this movie as much as everybody else, I still want to see "Mary Poppins Returns."

reviews.review_title: Walt Disney's Mary Poppins is still something worth marveling at all these years later
reviews.content: After over 30 years, I finally watched this classic Disney movie again, this time with my mom who admitted she had never seen this in its entirety before, after we both watched Saving Mr. Banks a few weeks ago. She was enchanted, as was I for the second time, with the entire thing. The songs by Richard B. and Robert M. Sherman are simply divine to listen to whether it's "A Spoonful of Sugar", "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocius", or the Oscar-winning "Chim-Chim-Cheree". Dick Van Dyke and Julie Andrews are a wonderful singing and dancing team here. By the way, Mr. Van Dyke maintains his charm despite having perhaps the worst fake British accent in motion picture history! Oh, and those animated sequences are some of Disney's best. Perhaps one can quibble that the musical sequences tend to be long for a family film making the whole thing possibly a chore to sit through sometimes. Still, there's so much to be amused and entertained by that this version of P.L. Travers' MP books can still be something to marvel at. Walt Disney really did himself proud here! So on that note, Mary Poppins is mostly "practically perfect in every way"!

reviews.review_title: What the Hell is a Tuppence?
reviews.content: Mary Poppins hasn't aged well to me. I know this is heresy, but I have always thought the movie over-long, forced, and too paint-by- the-numbers. Julie Andrews isn't that appealing of a character. Dick Van Dyke seems smudged (his soul, not his face). The kiddies are tedious, the dad's a jackass, and the only face I want to see is Glynis Johns. She was a radiant 16 in The 49th Parallel and a high- beamed knockout in Vault of Horrors (1973). Every time I've sat down to watch Mary Poppins, I've gotten bored. One set piece of singing and dancing and mixing live action with cartoons and dammit, those penguins are cute!But about the 300th number, I'm asking how many kids actually made it through Mary Poppins? I know I lost the climax of The Sound of Music when I was a 7 or 8 year old. I had to wait until NBC showed it in November, 1976 before I could watch the last 25 minutes or so. By then, I could appreciate how hot Heather Menzies was, and how, if you looked sideways and squinted, Julie Andrews could exude enough sex appeal to get the image of her in a nun's habit out of your mind.Maybe that's why I so dislike Mary Poppins. Even though it's a children's movie, the adult characters have to be appealing. Van Dyke looks hungover throughout the film--nothing for the girls. Andrews seems peeved and a tad screechy in that Victorian outfit. She reminds me of women I've known who were attractive until you looked into their eyes, and there was no laughter there. Yet, what does it matter? The movie premiered 50+ years ago, has been shown on VHS and DVD and, of course, TV about a million times. Folks loved and love it. Heck, I've got the Supercaliwhatever song in my head right now. I can hear Ed Wynn giggling. Tuppence, Tuppence! What the Hell is a Tuppence, anyway?
Mary Poppins is a beautiful movie. It's creative, original, beautiful, and really magical. How can you not love this?

reviews.review_title: Lovable songs, but the story is a little boring.
reviews.content: Mary Poppins remains one of Disney's most iconic movies. Based on P.L. Travers' "Mary Poppins" books, a nanny with magic powers comes to work for the Banks family, at the request of their children, to make the things right for the unhappy family.What I enjoyed about the movie is the memorable and lovable songs including Chim-Chim-Cheree, Spoonful of Sugar, Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious and Feed the Birds. Julie Andrews sung a majority of the movie's songs and she was absolutely brilliant. I also enjoyed the combination of live action with animated sequences - neatly done special effects and, combined with Mary Poppins' extraordinary powers, they let your imagination run wild. Which children wouldn't want to see a nanny gliding up and down the stairs and rearrange furniture in mid-air? Aside from the songs and animation, I thought the overall movie was pretty boring - lots of fillers and dragged-out drama and not enough adventure and fun. I thought Dick Van Dyke's portrayal of Bert was somewhat annoying, trying too hard to be over-zealously happy, and I thought the Mary Poppins character could have been more nurturing and kind-hearted to the children. She was, unfortunately, portrayed as somewhat cold and very stern to the kids.Overall, I thought this was an average film. Might be billed as some of Disney's best, but I think there are better live-action Disney movies from that time.Grade C

reviews.review_title: Who the heck gave this a six?
reviews.content: This is a masterpiece. Julie Andrews is absolutely brilliant and it has a great plot that kids can understand. My two year old loved it. When she saw the Sound of Music she immediately recognized Julie Andrews as Mary Poppins. This is an instant classic

reviews.review_title: Mary Poppins is nothing so atrocious, supercalifragaliciousexpealidocious!
reviews.content: Great watch, would watch again, and can recommend.This movie holds up amazingly well, and despite the "bad" green screen work, actually has some very rather impressive effects, to include reverse cinematography, wire work, and cartoon-reality interaction. Mind you, it's no "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?", but "Cool Wold" is the only other movie I can think of at this moment that even has that.There is quite a bit of establishing scenes, but that was common enough in 1964. The writing, if wonky, is actually structured quite well, we're shown reason enough to care about the character, when we're meant to (maybe not the staff...possibly the wife), but we're either offered joy or gruffness early on.While Mary Poppins is presented as a magical character, not all of the characters are quite aware that is the case (in fairness, no one tries to burn her as a witch either), and quite let her have the run of it: the father being the most, if poorly, resistant. It feels as though the movie has a message of being attractive enough can cause magical things to happen and you needn't worry about the reality of things, such as money. But I might be reading too far into it.When it comes down to it, this movie is a delightful, if weird, time with positive morals imparted on the audience, young and old.If you liked "The Return of Mary Poppins", then I suggest you watch this before they finally reboot this one.

I won't go deeply into the plot there is a lot to give an in depth dive into the plot . Instead I will say how much this movie means to me. Yes the Banks family is looking for a nanny the parents are busy . They love their children but it's the thing to do in their class and they never consider otherwise. Mary Poppins and Bert as well teaches parents and children that they need each other. Their time together is precious. Don't leave it to a nanny or others anymore than necessary. The lesson is timeless. The songs are fun, memorable, engaging and meaningful. Beautiful sets abound . This film maybe be set in the 1910's but the message fits any time.

reviews.review_title: I'm not an impatient person, but this seemed to go on forever...
reviews.content: Shame to say this but this movie just seemed too long. I'm not an impatient person but this movie unfortunately lead me to boredom. Though at first entertained by great songs and acting, a similar repetitive story occurred: a lot of music, similar storylines and emotions portrayed. Though I must say this is a great storyline and I hope to see the sequel: being modern with better animation, sound and more magical. I found this a disappointment which was a shame since the actors were really good and I have enjoyed many other movies they participate in. Sorry to everyone who may find this review offensive but I would not recommend this.

reviews.review_title: Princess Fiona's mother meets the Man Who Tripped over the Ottoman
reviews.content: Obviously, everyone knows about "Mary Poppins". The title character (Julie Andrews) is a practically-perfect-in-every-way-nanny in 1910 London. Answering an ad by the pampered children of banker George Banks (David Tomlinson), she arrives in the house and teaches the children her philosophy: a spoonful of sugar makes the medicine go down. With the help of her chimney-sweep friend Bert (Dick Van Dyke), she shows the children the magical world that they have been denied. The major challenge will be bringing their father out of his stuffy world.Most people treat "Mary Poppins" as a cute family movie, but I would like to analyze it further. First off, mother Winifred (Glynis Johns) is a suffragist. If it was nothing but a simple "family movie", they probably wouldn't have shown this (granted, it's good that they showed this). Oh, and about Mary Poppins' sugar-based philosophy: wouldn't that cause osteoporosis? Or at least tooth decay? But most important of all is Dick Van Dyke's attempt at a cockney accent: he did a terrible job. As I was watching the movie, every time Dick Van Dyke was on screen, I made some comment relating to "The Dick Van Dyke Show": Tripped over too many ottomans, Rob? Laura's not gonna like it if she finds you with this woman. What would Buddy and Sally think? Has Buddy made any comments about Cooley's bald head today? Dick Van Dyke's strength is in his dance numbers (he always has been good at that kind of stuff). I guess that overall, "Mary Poppins" was a worthy movie, especially since it spawned some spoofs: in one of Gilligan's dream sequences, Lovey is Mary Poppins, and the Simpsons once had a nanny named Sherry Bobbins.As for the other cast members, Ed Wynn plays tipsy Uncle Albert, who just floats around, and Mr. Dawes, Jr., is played by Arthur Malet, who later appeared on "I Dream of Jeannie" as Jeannie's cockney uncle Vasmir, who must decide whether or not Maj. Nelson will make an acceptable husband.Maybe it's not all that supercalifragilisticexpialidocious, but you might feel like flying a kite after seeing it.

reviews.review_title: Weighty Disney whimsy combines magic with sermonizing...
reviews.content: Julie Andrews is indeed quite magical as P. L. Travers' Mary Poppins, sailing up the banister to mend a dysfunctional household comprised of a British banker, his suffragette wife and their two precocious children; however, Andrews is like a brightly-painted saint, not above having a little mischievous fun but perhaps too logical and practical to be perfect. This set-bound Disney musical isn't very airy, with a narrative that is by turns happily frantic and deadly earnest. Andrews doesn't get lost in the plastic din, but rarely does she have a genuinely moving moment (even the lullaby sequence is less a sweet break in the action than just a preamble to more chaos). Casting Dick Van Dyke as a Cockney chimney sweep doesn't pay off--his accent is deplorable, to be charitable--but the kids are cute and Julie doesn't overdo her twinkle. Acting like a common sense anchor, Andrews makes a fine substitute teacher, however I would've preferred a bit more magic and a tad less sermonizing. **1/2 from ****

reviews.review_title: Walt Disney Pictures at its best
reviews.content: This is, in my opinion, the best Disney classic. With a fantastic story, very good special effects, good actors and good characters, has ALL good. I really recommend it to everyone.

Mary Poppins is, without a doubt, the finest non-animated film in the Disney canon (yes, there is lots of animation) and a genuine classic.I won't repeat what's been said in the many fine reviews here on IMDb, I'll just say that there are a few problems that are glaring and make the film a tad less enjoyable for me: 1. Dick van Dyke's cockney accent is horrible. He sounds like an American imitating a Londoner trying to imitate a cockney. It's bloody awful! While I find his singing and dancing admirable and entertaining, his speaking voice is nails-on-slate. Had the producers just dubbed his speaking voice with that of Michael Caine - a real cockney - I wouldn't find this so annoying. This is tune out number one.2. The film is too long. Some judicious cutting, especially of a couple of the lesser musical numbers, would have been in order. Also, the final boardroom scene in the bank goes on for far too long.This is outweighed by the utter charm of the whole thing and the near-magical presence of the splendid Julie Andrews - a performer worthy of admiration if there ever was one. This is a woman with talent, incredible personal charm, and true charisma. She is a leading lady, pure and simple. She more than makes up for the aforementioned minor problems for every second she is on screen is magic.One glaring omission from all the reviews I've read is an appreciation of the two ladies who played the elder servants in the household - the American character actress Reta Shaw and the British Hermione Baddley (sp?). Both lend top-notch support and are quite wonderful, especially Shaw, who was one of the most popular and talented character actresses of her era. (She is best remembered for her semi-recurring role on TV's BEWITCHED and for her presence in most of Doris Day's films.) Shaw was a skilled song-and-dance performer with a deep voice and commanding presence and a master scene stealer.

I hate to love Disney, but this orgy of sugary spoon-feeding is (almost) irresistible. It's episodic, i.e. undramatic, it's overlong, it's simple-minded... and absolutely marvelous! The tunes are catchy as hell, Julie Andrews is a real Dame with charm to boot (and strangely attractive in her nanny outfit), van Dyke's lamentable Cockney-turn gets funnier with each viewing and the animated sequences add a nice touch of day-dreaming.There's good kitsch and bad kitsch. This is one of the greatest good kitsch movies. Watch another Julie Andrews performance in one of the worst bad kitsch movies: The Sound of Music.8 out of 10 Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!es

reviews.review_title: Classic Musical That Never Loses its Luster
reviews.content: Let's face it, MARY POPPINS does have its shortcomings: Dick van Dyke's execrable cockney accent, and a narrative that tends to sprawl - especially during the last two-thirds of the movie. But such comments are essentially irrelevant in a film whose songs are instantly memorable. I defy anyone not to emerge from the theater (or from the tablet) singing "Supercallifragilisticexpiallidocious" or "A Spoonful of Sugar," or "Let's Go Fly a Kite." I defy anyone not to have a lump in the throat as Julie Andrews sings "Feed the Birds," or to enjoy the sheer brio of the sequence celebrating "It's a Jolly Holiday with Mary." Julie Andrews is quite simply breathtaking; one understands from her performance just how good she must have been as the original Eliza Dolittle in MY FAIR LADY (and how mistaken Jack Warner was in casting Audrey Hepburn in the film version). Van Dyke gives a jaunty performance, while David Tomlinson steals the show as Mr. Banks, the bank official who learns there is is much more to life than simply earning money. The film is the kind of thing that can be watched again and again - which is why it is endlessly repeated (and revived in cinemas as a companion-piece to SAVING MR. BANKS).
Filled with great music, groundbreaking visual effects, surprisingly mature themes and (overall) charm, "Mary Poppins" is a great example of movie magic.
And she received her first academy award.Wonderful music,excellent combination cartoons and live action,amazing choreography and a timeless classic for all ages.

Well, it wasn't quite supercalifragiliciousexpialadocious (sp?) nor was it quite chim-chimney-chim-chimney-chim-chim-cheroo. It was fine as far as musicals go. To this day I only truly like one musical, and that is The Wizard of Oz.Mary Poppins was a string of musical numbers and dance sets to me. The idea of Mary Poppins the character is cool: a magical nanny that straightens out your kids and brings cheer to the household. I'd take such a nanny in a heartbeat it just didn't work for me as a musical.

I could have seen this when it came out, but fortunately or unfortunately I have no sentimental reasons for liking it. A lot of people have fond memories and I respect that ( I loved the terrible ' The Robe ' as a child but it is unbearable now. ) There are sequences like the chimney sweeps dancing on rooftops and for a moment I thought I was experiencing an out take of the wonderful ' West Side Story '. After that moment or two, aroused out of my boredom I continued to endure those dreadful songs. I do not want to comment on the two leads but I enjoyed glorious Glynis Johns, suffragette and oppressed at home. Her performance out classed the rest by miles. As for the Disney section it was boring, long and the so called magic of this sequence is put to shame beside ' Alice in Wonderland ' and ' Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs '. Hermione Baddeley was also on form, but this long, long film has some of the worst songs I have endured in any musical. I immediately rushed off and watched the raunchy, amazingly sexy ' Take Me To Town. ' The songs are not great in the Sirk film either, but they do not pretend to be and how I would have loved to see ' Ann Sheridan ' as Mary Poppins. 4 for those who recall with love and pleasure.

reviews.review_title: How Mary Poppins saved Mr Banks.
reviews.content: I had never seen 'Mary Poppins' but in this the 50th anniversary of that movie, and the recent Disney film 'Saving Mr Banks' with Tom Hanks, I knew I needed to see it to complete my enjoyment of the recent movie. Fortunately I found this on 50th anniversary Blu-Ray at my local public library. The picture and sound are remarkably good, as you would expect from such a special movie.Julie Andrews, still in her 20s and adorably cute, is Mary Poppins. The movie doesn't actually tell us much about her but as it opens we see her sitting in some clouds above London's Tower Bridge so we know there is something mystical about her. Then, when the Banks kids' torn-up note flies up the chimney and ends up in the possession of Mary Poppins we are assured there is something mystical about her.Being a Disney musical there are lots of songs and production numbers, a recurring phrase "a little bit of sugar makes the medicine go down" becomes the metaphor for the story, that a proper amount of fun and joy in life helps us cope with all of life's struggles. Mr Banks is a well- off London banker and too serious to have fun with his family, including his small son and small daughter. The mission of Mary Poppins is to save Mr Banks, to have him realize the importance of fun in life. After her mission is complete she presumably goes off and awaits another opportunity.A key scene in the middle has the kids going to work with their dad, the son has a tuppence (two pence) and wants to spend it on seed to feed the pigeons, but Mr Banks and the 5 other old men of the bank spend lots of energy trying to convince the boy to invest his money instead, it will help build bridges and railroads. Dick Van Dyke has two roles, first as Bert who is a sort of one-man band in the street, performing for tips. It is clear he has already knows Mary Poppins and has some sort of mystical powers also, but his character remains a bit unclear. In heavy makeup he also plays Mr. Dawes Senior, the senior banking executive. I knew Van Dyke mainly for his later TV roles, and it was a joy seeing him sing and dance as a younger man.David Tomlinson is good as Mr. Banks and Glynis Johns is good as the wife Mrs. Banks, always busy going off to one event or another and leaving the house and children to the maid, the cook, and the nanny.

Marvellous film and made long before computer special effects....have always wondered in the scene with David Tomlinson grumpy at breakfast...when the Admirals cannon sounds the white statue bust rocks precariously on its plinth but miraculously stays put!.....a happy accident...or the result of many takes!?....

This was a big movie for Julie Andrews and also Dick Van Dyke. Much loved and well made - although I can't agree that it's "perfect". I loved this film when I first saw it in original release and remember the 'I love to laugh' floating in the air scene and also the "feed the birds" scenes of St Pauls which had a haunting quality. Seeing it again on DVD the film holds up well and my 10 year daughter loves it too so it still has the same appeal for todays kids.  Again a movie which very much needs to be seen on a big screen to enjoy it the most. Disneys film version of Travers books does make some changes that the author did not necessarily like however film audiences have enjoyed it for many years so who cares. Likely to remain 'Perfectly popular' for many years yet. A great fun fantasy ride for everyone. I think Dick Van Dykes best scenes were playing Mr Dawes of the bank. Julie Andrews in her peak years .It won't come round again. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: A Bit Too Happy, Long, And Sugar-Coated, For My Tastes
reviews.content: Many have considered Mary Poppins to be among Disney's finest movies. Among the first films to simultaneously show live-action and animation, the film's settings and choreography are stunningly beautiful, and certainly represent a crowning achievement.However, Mary Poppins suffers from being over-long, having too many pointless songs, and expanding too much energy at once, which hurts the story line. Everyone is singing, giggling, or laughing on cue as if they have had too many "Spoonfuls of Sugar." (pun intended.) Even the songs are a mixed review. "Feed The Birds" may be one of the most enduring timeless songs ever written. But jumping around to "Chim Chim Cheree" and the ever too long "Step in Time" dance sequence is WAAAAAY overdone.I also hate the "I Love to Laugh" sequence, probably because Ed Wynn's voice terrified me as a child and still gives me the creeps. He just looks and sounds like some dirty old man that your parents told you to stay away from.A point is that Mary Poppins has a song for every happy mood and it doesn't seem to end. I read that at one point over 30 songs were written for the film. Can you believe that? No wonder they had to cut the music down! The storyline is trite and obvious, "Kids need love and attention, not just wealthy surroundings to be happy." Well, did we need 2 hours and 20 minutes to know that? Furthermore, anyone who has to endure Dick Van Dyke's HORRIBLE attempt at a Cockney accent should be rewarded.Tighter script editing without breaking into a song, dance, giggle, or laugh every 10 minutes, might have made for a better movie storyline.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever!!!
reviews.content: This movie is a smashing hit. The music is amazing, the idea is brilliant! I do not think there is anyone in the western world who hasn't seen, one of Walt Disney's greatest movies ever... For those who haven't seen this movie I will ONLY tell you the plot to avoid spoiling the movie. The movie revolves around an unhappy family, who are called the "Banks" and the Chaos theory as Mary Poppins, who is the main character, a wonderful nanny is inserted into the Banks family. The children go from "Be seen and not heard" "Be heard and seen". The movie also mixes humans and animation figures which is quite well done. I think this movie is a spectacular and everyone should see this movie at least once...

reviews.review_title: A narcissistic nanny with Jedi powers gets her employer fired and his ex-boss killed.
reviews.content: Dick Van Dyke, whose amazing name should have been snatched by a half-dozen porn actors (and actresses) by now, does one of the worst cockney accents of all times. A little later, Glynis Johns, a bad mother only concerned with her goofy feminist cause, comes home and starts singing some silly, badly written tune with non-rhyming lyrics. Her two maids join in (fearing being fired, perhaps, if they didn't). Her husband looks like Angela Lansbury; he's the uptight banker.MP gives a strange taste of its occasionally dubious morals early on. Merry Poppings uses her Jedi powers to get rid of all the other applicants for the nanny position. The Dark Side bitch doesn't even have the decency to show up on time, unlike all the other women who came early, and then she simply blows them away! What an interesting message for the kiddies. The hypocrite that she is, she then teaches Mr. Lansbury a "career isn't everything" moral lesson. This coming from a woman who unkindly nudges her competition; Mary Poopins has no problems using HER elbows in the rat-nany-race."Never judge things by their appearance," this tricky Jedi Master says, and then just a minute later adds: "A thing of beauty is a joy forever." What are the kids supposed to learn from these contradicting pieces of advice? Stop confusing them kids, Mary Poopins! Get your act straight. AND she's a narcissist. "Mary Poopins: practically perfect in every way." So powerful is she that all the cartoon animals shower her with compliments, constantly. Could it be that they fear her wrath and powerful magic trickery? Those animals have no pride at all. "A spoon-full of sugar makes the medicine go down". Besides being a song about illness (her first song, and she goes straight for the jugular), I can personally attest that a spoonful of sugar makes the vomit reflex turn on. And "chim-chim chiminey chim-chim charoo." What the bloody hell is that? What if I said "hoobdaboop-doopery beep-beep nagrook-pa-nooj". Can I write a Hollywood script too, please? Old guy: "How long do you want your underwear? And he says: I want it from March to September! Ha-ha-haaa!" Mary Poppins: "You silly old geezer, that is the sh*tt*est pun I've ever heard." Now, that's the kind of Merry Poopings I'd love to see.In the end, Mary Poopings gets her employer fired, his ex-boss gets a heart attack and dies, and the kids' father gets his old job back! So Merry "Grim Reaper" Poopings succeeded in what she set out to do: get Lansbury to take more care of the kids and to put an old man into a grave (but not before letting him levitate for a bit). Merry Poopings is not so much a kids film as it's a girl's film. Little boys want to see death, destruction and pirates, not overly cheerful animals giving compliments to each other and getting along. Hence one could call this a "kids' chick-flick". No wonder it won so many Oscars, chick-flicks usually do. Plus the fact that these special-effects were state-of-the-art for the Stone-Age 60s, when this movie must have seemed like "Star Wars" when it came out. Nevertheless, between Dick's laughable English accent and the corny but colourful musical numbers, I wasn't bored. MP is fairly entertaining, if perhaps occasionally for the wrong reasons, and anyway immeasurably better than "My Fair Lady" which is one of the dullest turds in cinema's history.Who knows what other directors would have done with this story. I wonder.Pier Pasolini's version of MP: an incestual family goes to a church where they strip naked and watch the priest ejaculate.Ingmar Bergman's version of MP: a nanny can't get over her three miscarriages, later committing suicide in front of the kids.Spike Lee's version of MP: a ghetto nanny gets raped and hung by her white employer for trying to teach the kids about African history.

Odds are good you've seen Mary Poppins, it came out in 1964 and is a pop-culture touchstone. If you haven't seen it, go see it, I'm going to be getting pretty spoilery in this review. Go see it, that's the short version of this review.This was a hard one to review as I grew up watching this one frequently. I hadn't seen it in many years before this write-up and attempted to watch the movie with fresh eyes. That said, I've loved this movie since before I could walk, so there's my bias. I'll be as objective as possible, but it is what it is.The first thing that struck me upon re-watching this film was just how very weird it is. It has a level of quirk usually only seen in indie comedies these day. Think about it, there's a possibly homeless man who is the only character that recognizes the audience and communicates with them directly, but not as a narrator, as a friend. There are two men who live on top of a house and shoot cannons across the city; one is named, of course, Admiral Boom. The children's mother and their cook have a no-nonsense discussion about saving rotten eggs to throw at the prime minister. An umbrella decides to start talking 5 min from the end of the film, it was never really set up as a character, but it is now apparently! This is one odd duck of a movie!Another element that leapt out at me is just how full of herself Mary Poppins really is! She's a perfect combination of straight-laced confidence and cunning manipulator. Mary isn't here for the kids, they're not that bad to begin with, she's here to knock some sense into their father...to force him to BE their father. She's utterly amazing!The songs are catchy and occasionally moving, the antiquated visual effects still hold up incredibly well, and the story is equal parts fanciful and emotional. There's a mix here of kid-centric material, such as an entire sequence linking loss of gravity to uncontrollable laughter, as well as sequences that will hit adults right in the feels. The section of the film where the children's father, Mr. Banks is walking to work late at night to his own career's end is heartbreaking. The camera angles, the music, the lack of dialogue, this is one of my favorite parts of the movie.The movie often gets distracted by it's own rabbit trails, which can lead to some portions dragging a bit. Some of the songs go on far too long but, perhaps it's my bias, I find myself disappointed when these bits end. From a strict film-making standpoint, songs like "feed the birds" don't feed the story, but I think they go a long way towards establishing a feeling, a tone for the film. One that sticks with its audience long after the credits have rolled.The acting here is all pretty great. Dick Van Dyke turns in a hilariously bad attempt at a cockney accent but, once again this could be my bias, but it kind of ends up becoming part of the character and making him all the more crazy and charming. The kids are cute, but not too cute. Mrs Banks, Glynis Johns, is perfection as a staunch feminist in the streets and a subservient housewife as soon as her husband shows up. Her struggle to maintain both sides of her is underplayed to perfection and is one of my favorite character through-lines of the movie. Mr Banks is played by the ever-typecast David Tomlinson. This is the role he was born to play and he totally sells the overbearing control-freak workaholic who's entire life is crumbling around him.But the standout is, of course, Mary Poppins herself. Julie Andrews IS Mary Poppins and Mary Poppins IS Julie Andrews. I will never believe otherwise. From her deadpan delivery of hilarious lines to her angelic singing voice, Julie Andrews dominates this movie. She is the dark mysterious figure, frightening and strange. She is the warm teacher, pulling back the veil on just how amazing every-day life is to the entire Banks family. She is the relationship doctor, knowing exactly what's wrong, how to cure it, and how to bend the people in her way from enemy to unwitting ally. Mary Poppins is a force of nature and without Julie Andrews, this movie would not have half the impact and relevance it still holds to this day.If you love musicals, watch Mary Poppins.If you love amazing practical visual effects, watch Mary Poppins.If you enjoy interesting, comedic characters, watch Mary Poppins.If you have never seen Mary Poppins, watch Mary Poppins.If you've watched it many times, watch it again.In my opinion, Mary Poppins is "practically perfect in every way".-Josh Evans

This is one of my top favourite family movies, I loved it since my childhood. Everything in this movie is perfect: Julie Andrews is perfect as Mary Poppins, and truly deserved the Oscar for Best Actress, and Dick Van Dyke is just hilarious as Bert, in his best performance of his career (and I liked him in the first Night at the Museum movie). And all the other supporting actors are great: David Tomlinson and Glynis Johns are perfect as the parents, and so Jane Darwell as the old pigeon feeder and Ed Wynn as the always floating Uncle Albert is very wise-cracking.The songs are charming, as well the animated sequences with the penguins and the fox hunters. Loved also the chimney cleaners sequence, very hilarious. And this movie teaches great values too.In substance a truly masterpiece and one of the best family movies ever made! I recommend it to everyone, and have a great time watching it!

I'm still trying to think of one word that could possibly sum up this film. Oh yeah. (singing) It's supercalifragilisticexpialidocious! Even though the sound of adaptations sound atrocious, if you give this one a chance you'll find it's quite precocious. SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS! Based off the original trilogy (or more books?) Mary Poppins was about a magical no nonsense nanny who looks after the Banks' children and they encounter all sorts of adventures in the simplest places like parks, shopping, and visiting relatives. I've been reading the books and I'll admit I wish I could have seen Disney do more like the zoo at night, a traveling compass, and so on, but for what we got it was terrific. True that Mary Poppins, herself, has been disneyfied, but the directors don't leave out the fact that she's a grumpy character who for some reason is into magic, but later denies it ever happened. Aside from Emma Thompson (who probably wasn't available at the time - but played a different Mary Poppins) I can't think of anyone better to play the role other than Julie Andrews. She was excellent. I love Bert (even if he can't pull off a good British accent). Next to Mary Poppins, he is so charming and imaginative. I still love his one man band, and any of the song and dance numbers he's in. The kids are great, the father - oh I love him! Ed Wynn as Uncle Albert, I'M GONNA DIE! Nobody could play a better flying, laughing guy than him! Oh and that laughter is CONTAGIOUS! If I go through the whole cast it will be too much, so in short, the cast was perfect! Don't ask me what my favorite scene is because it's too hard to choose! Almost every scene is my favorite! I love the kids with Mary Poppins, getting to know the family, the bank, chimney sweepers, and the kite scene. Every moment of the film had me wishing I was there, it even made cleaning up my room look fun (too bad snapping fingers won't help)! The songs? If you mention one verse from any of the songs to someone else then don't be surprised if they start singing the whole song out loud! They're hilarious, they're catchy, they're sweet, they're nostalgic, they're touching, they're upbeat, they're sincere, they're adorable, and so on! It keeps the balance of having cheerful moments but also having tender realistic moments. In fact Walt Disney's favorite song was Feed the Birds, because it talked about showing your care for other people. So as you can see it has a mixed message, but it keeps it in a perfect balance: it lets kids be kids, while at the same time teaching everyone young and old to not take life for granted. For example, there's a scene when Mr. Banks refuses to give tuppence to an old lady to feed birds, but scenes later when he decides to, she's gone. Not sure if that's suppose to indicate that she died or just left, but it shows that when you find a chance to show kindness you should take that chance because you may not have another chance. Yes the film didn't quite follow the expectations of the book, but in this case I say that it was almost captured the heart of the story even if there were added songs, scenes, and characters, but hey at least there are no forced morals or added villains. It's actually nice to see a movie without villains. Overall it's a great adaptations and one of few (or many) that stayed true to the heart of the story. It was practically perfect in every way.

reviews.review_title: Fairy tale, but missed the punch?
reviews.content: It could be called a very good movie, as fairy tale, and on that count there is no doubt of its merit. However it missed the punch point, and probably that's why the author, Ms Travers, wasn't too happy with it. Of course I am not sure that could be the reason of the relation having deteriorated so much, that Disney didn't even bother to invite her for premiere? That was not only disrespect, but an affront. But the studios, most of all this one, had that ego, and the 'master of all' attitude, so nothing too strange about it. Probably that was one of the reasons, the great Bernard Shaw publicly told, and carried it out too, that he won't have anything to do with Hollywood. The point won't have been missed, had that not been mentioned, and that too quite significantly, in the movie. It is I would say, all the male, head of family's lament, right or wrong, immaterial. That he grinds himself, to take care of the family, silently, whereas the family isn't, "cares" about him. That part is depicted well here too, the wife is a socializing woman, the children, probably due to his hard exterior, are scared of him. No one really dares, or cares, to enter his psyche. This isn't always his fault, but under the circumstances, he thought, he must be like this. To shatter this shell was important. This isn't the first, or only movie, where this subject is brought up. Philadelphia Story is another one of many. But in none of them, the solution, or even the right message is brought out, the conversion of the family, to melt the wall. This aspect had always been buried, and a passing remark, in the main story.But what happens when this is the raison d'etre of the tale? This particular fact was twice mentioned by Mary Poppins, with significance. But practically I couldn't find, the children doing much about that. The Mary Poppins series, was reportedly influenced by author's repentance, of not caring enough to help her father (who incidentally was too a banker, died while he was just in his early forties, reportedly demise hastened due to Alcoholism). Had they skipped to mention it, probably the movie won't have lost anything, in its story line. But retaining it, and doing nothing about it, really gives a wrong message, as if it is the father, who should break the mould itself. The Beast should become prince charming, without tears of Belle. Any good fairy tales should have an underlying message, for the children. Cinderella tells the children not to be despondent of the circumstances, with the persons who are kind (there would be a few), you could rise up. La Belle et la Bête teaches not to be overtly scared or affected by the exterior, there could be something exquisite underneath, to be discovered. Little Mermaid tells, for someone whom you really care, no sacrifice is enough. Like that this too had a message, in fact may be all of the above together, which the movie version missed.

When two children have family problems in 1910 London, a mysterious nanny arrives and brings magic into their lives.Mary Poppins has been part of my life since I saw it when it first came out, at the age of 12. Since then, I have become aware of areas of criticism. One of these is the special effects, for which the film won an Oscar. I have to say that I don't disagree here: I think many of the effects were not that good, even by the standards of 1964: however, it was only a two-horse race that year.The other is, of course, Dick Van Dyke's atrocious cockernee accent. It is difficult to deny just how bad this is, but I think it is unfair to uncouple it from the rest of Van Dyke's performance. It is a major performance of great charm and exceptional physical ability (in terms of both grace and knockabout humour), and the inaccuracy of the accent is a minor negative against such great positives.We then have to add in the great songs, the wonderful art design, and Julie Andrews' luminous performance, and we arrive at a classic which fully deserves its classic status.

Mary Poppins (1964): Dir: Robert Stevenson / Cast: Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, David Tomlinson, Glymis Johns, Ed Wynn: Tremendous accomplishment from Disney about the mysterious nanny who descends from the clouds via umbrella. Her background is not given but she is tasked with taking care of two active children. They seek adventure and thrills but Mary Poppins uses methods that make cleaning the bedroom and such a visual charm. This is a breakthrough triumph in visual effects with Poppins joining hands with the children and literally jumping into a sidewalk drawing for further adventures. Director Robert Stevenson is at his best but the true attraction is the wondrous presence of Julie Andrews as Poppins. Dick Van Dyke plays Bert, a sort of jack-of-all-trades who is familiar with Poppins and embraces her presence with charm and physical antics of his own. David Tomlinson plays Mr. Banks, strict traditional father who works at the bank. Glynis Johns plays Mrs. Banks who cheerfully fights for the up rise of women. Ed Wynn plays Uncle Albert who suffers from some laughing condition that causes him to float. The result is a heavily layered family film that teaches the importance of fatherhood as well as not growing up too quickly. Visually stunning with great songs about "spoonfuls of sugar." As Poppins herself would say, this film is "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!" Score: 9 / 10

reviews.review_title: The story, music and actors propel Poppins to the stars
reviews.content: "Mary Poppins" will last for generations as one of the best children's musical films of all time. It is a movie for kids of all ages, from two to 92. This 1964 movie was the biggest project that Walt Disney and his studio had ever tackled. It was the first big Disney live action fantasy produced as a musical. And, it was a smashing success. What's not to like about this film? It has much to enjoy, from the music, dance routines, animated sequences, fantasy special effects, and an amusing story with a message. All of the cast excel in this film. Much ado has been made about Dick Van Dyke's poor rendition of a Cockney accent. He slips in and out of it at times. It's quite obvious, but I think way too much is made of it. For a serious film or drama that would be a major detraction. But this is a film that has much whimsy, fantasy and fun in it. And, consider the rest of his character and performance. He has some good singing and comedic sequences and his dance routines are outstanding. He gives an excellent overall portrayal of Bert, and is hilarious in a second role as Mr. Dawes Senior. But for his poor Cockney accent, Van Dyke might have earned an Oscar nomination. David Tomlinson, Glynis Johns, the rest of the adult actors and the kids all give very good performances. Much more should be said about Julie Andrews. Before 1964, she had appeared only in a few TV movies and series. Her lead in "Mary Poppins" firmly established her as a movie star. Andrews was a talented actress who later played in dramatic roles and mystery-action films. But, she was most known and loved for her singing in musicals. Four of her films will likely keep Andrews in the spotlight for the next few generations. Besides "Mary Poppins," she made "Cinderella," "The Sound of Music" and "Thoroughly Modern Millie." This film competed with a host of excellent films in the 1964 Academy Awards. It won five Oscars and had eight more nominations. "My Fair Lady" took eight Oscars, including best picture and best actor (Rex Harrison). Among those won by "Mary Poppins" were best actress for Julie Andrews (see more about that below) and two Oscars for music. Richard and Robert Sherman wrote and composed all the music and songs for "Mary Poppins." The Sherman Brothers worked many years for Disney and produced some of the best and most popular whimsical songs of filmdom. Three of their songs from this film became popular tunes: "Chim Chim Cher-ee," "A Spoonful of Sugar," and "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious."I enjoyed watching this film again after so many years; and one of the pluses on the DVD I bought is the background video it has about the movie. It includes a snippet from the 1964 Academy Awards. Andrews had starred in the stage production of "My Fair Lady," and wanted to get the part in that movie. But Warner Brothers was wary of trying a relatively new actress for a major film and instead chose Audrey Hepburn for its lead. Hepburn was excellent in her role, but it was Andrews who won the best actress Oscar that year. In her acceptance speech, she complimented Warner Brothers for its excellent movie and thanked Jack Warner for his casting choice (which led to her getting the "Mary Poppins" lead instead, and the Oscar).
